content:
type='text' text='A. P. J. Abdul Kalam, full name Avul Pakir Jainulabdeen Abdul Kalam, was an Indian aerospace scientist and politician who served as the 11th President of India from 2002 to 2007. He was born on October 15, 1931, in Rameswaram, Tamil Nadu, India, and passed away on July 27, 2015.

Kalam played a leading role in India's civilian space program and military missile development efforts, which earned him the nickname "Missile Man of India." He was closely involved in the country's efforts to develop its nuclear technology and was a key figure in the Pokhran-II nuclear tests conducted in 1998. Prior to his presidency, he worked with the Defence Research and Development Organisation (DRDO) and the Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO).

Kalam was known not just for his scientific contributions but also for his commitment to education and inspiring young minds. After serving as President, he remained active in education, writing, and public service until his death. His dedication to public service, humility, and vision for a developed India have left a lasting legacy.' annotations=None
